sentences.sentence: Having done all this, I left them the next day, and went on board the ship.
When I left this island, I carried on board the great goat-skin cap I had made, my umbrella, and one of my parrots( 鹦鹉 ).
I left the island on the 19th of December in the year 1686, after I had been upon it twenty-eight years, two months, and nineteen days.
I arrived in England on the 11th of June, in the year 1687, having been thirty-five years absent.
When I came to England, I was as perfect a stranger to everyone, as if I had never been known there.
My good friend the widow( 寡妇 ), with whom I had left my money, was alive, but had become a widow( 寡妇 ) a second time.
I told her to forget all of what she owed( 欠 ) me, as thanks to her for her former care and loyalty( 忠诚 ) to me.
I helped her as much as my money would afford, which at that time allowed me to do little for her, but I promised her I would never forget her former kindness to me.
I went to Yorkshire( 约克郡，地名 ), but my father was dead, and my mother and all the family were gone also.
I found nothing to relieve or help me, and the little money I had could not do much for me to settle in the world.
I decided to go to Lisbon( 里斯本，地名 ), and see if I might not get some information of the state of my farm in the Brazils, and what had happened to my former neighbor and partner.
With this plan I set out for Lisbon, where I arrived in April.
My man Friday accompanied( 陪伴 ) me very honestly in all these travels.
When I came to Lisbon, I found my old friend, the captain of the ship, who first took me up at sea off the shore of Africa.
After some sincere( 真诚的 ) expressions of the old acquaintance( 交情 ) between us, I asked about my farm and my partner.
The old man told me he had not been in the Brazils for about nine years, but that he could assure( 向...保证 ) me that as far as he knew my partner was still living.
He believed I would have a very good account of the improvement of the farm, for my partner had kept his promise that if I returned, I could take back my share of the property.
He also said that my partner was now extremely rich.
He believed I would find a very considerable( 相当多的 ) amount of money when I asked.
Remembering what he had done for me, I could hardly stop myself from crying at what he had said to me.
I told him if ever I had possession of the farm I would return to repay( 回报 ) him for his kindness.
When this was past, the old man told me that he could help me to make my claim( 提出对…的所有权 ) to my farm.
He told me I just had to enter my name in a public register( 注册薄 ), showing proof( 证明 ) that I was alive, and then stay with him till I heard some news.
In less than seven months, I received a large packet from my partner in the farm, in which were documents making me aware of my fortune:—
First, there was the account of the value of my farm.
Secondly, there was a letter of my partner’s, congratulating me very affectionately upon my being alive.
He gave me an account how the farm was improved, and what it produced a year.
I was now owner, all on a sudden, of more than five thousand pounds, and had a farm in the Brazils, producing more than a thousand pounds a year.
In short, I was in a condition which I barely( 几乎不 ) knew how to understand.
The first thing I did was to repay( 报答 ) my good old friend the captain, who had been kind to me in my beginning, and honest to me at the end.
I told him that, next to( 仅次于… ) the goodness of Heaven, it was owing( 归功于 ) to him, and drew up( 拟定 ) legal papers( 文件 ) giving him an annual( 每年的 ) income out of my wealth in the Brazils.
I now thought about what to do next, and what to do with the farm that God had thus put into my hands.
At first I thought of my old friend the widow( 寡妇 ), who had been very good to me, and to whom I felt I owed( 亏欠 ) a great deal.
So, the first thing I did was to get a merchant( 商人 ) in Lisbon to carry to her a hundred pounds from me.
I thought of going to the Brazils and settling there, for I was used to the place, but I had some worries in my mind about religion.
When I began to think of living and dying there, I began to fear that Catholicism( 天主教 ) might not be the best religion to die with.
I decided to sell my farm, and wrote to my old partner in the Brazils.
He accepted my offer to sell, and sent thirty-three thousand pieces of eight( 八里亚尔币（旧时西班牙银币） ) to pay for it.
And thus I had given the first part of my life to fortune and adventure.
It began foolishly, but closed much more happily than seemed likely at the time.
Most people would think that in this state of good fortune, I was past( 再也不会做 ) risking any more danger.
But I was used to a wandering life, and had neither family nor many relations.
Though I had sold my farm in the Brazils, yet I could not keep that country out of my head, and had a great mind to travel again.
Especially I could not resist( 抗拒 ) the strong desire I had to see my island, and to know if the poor Spaniards( 西班牙人 ) were still alive there.
But my true friend, the widow( 寡妇 ), begged me not to go, so much that for almost seven years she prevented my running abroad.
In the meantime( 同时 ), I got married, and had three children, two sons and one daughter.
But my wife died, and my desire to go abroad remained.
I thus decided to go as a private trader to the East Indies( 东印度群岛 ) in the year 1694.
In this voyage I visited my new colony( 殖民地 ) on the island.
I saw my replacements the Spaniards, and heard the old story of their lives and of the criminals I left there.
At first these men had cursed( 咒骂 ) the poor Spaniards, and at last the Spaniards were forced to use violence with them.
Their history was as full of variety( 变化 ) and wonderful accidents as my own had been, particularly their battles with the natives, who landed several times upon the island.
Five of them also made an attempt to reach the mainland, and brought away eleven men and five women as prisoners.
Thus I found about twenty young children on the island.
Here I stayed about twenty days. I left them supplies of all necessary things.
Besides this, I shared the lands into parts with them, and kept to myself the ownership of the whole, but gave them such parts as we agreed on.
Having settled all things with them, I left them there.
From there I went to the Brazils, from where I sent a ship back with more people to the island.
In it, besides other supplies, I sent seven women as workers, or as wives if anyone wanted to marry them.
I sent them also five cows, and some pigs.
But all these things, with some very surprising incidents in some new adventures of my own, for ten years more, I shall explain in the Second Part of my Story.

article_info.previous: 昨天我们读到Robinson和英国船长一起夺回本该属于船长的船，并成功劝服两个不忠诚的囚犯留在岛上。
article_info.share_words: Having done all this, I left them the next day, and went on board the ship. When I left this island, I carried on board the great goat-skin cap I had made, my umbrella, and one of my parrots.

question.cn: 以下哪句话是正确的？
question.en: Which of the following statements is true?

options.cn: Robinson把岛上所有的东西都带回了英国。
options.en: Robinson took everything he had on the island back to England.

options.cn: 当Robinson回到英国的时候，每个人都认识他。
options.en: Everybody knew Robinson when he came back to England.

options.cn: Robinson的那个寡妇好朋友还活着。
options.en: Robinson's good friend the widow, was alive.

analysis: 文中说：“When I left the island, I carried on board the great goat-skin cap I had made, my umbrella, and one of my parrots.”“When I came to England, I was as perfect a stranger to everyone.”“My good friend the widow...was alive.”因此选C。

question.cn: Robinson回到约克郡的时候，他父亲还活着吗？
question.en: Was Robinson’s father still alive when he returned to Yorkshire?

options.en: Yes, he was.
No, he wasn't.
We don't know.

analysis: 文中说：“I went to Yorkshire, but my father was dead, and my mother and all the family were gone also.”所以选B。

question.cn: Robinson在巴西的农场怎么了？
question.en: What happened to Robinson’s farm in Brazil?

options.en: It belonged to a Brazilian.

options.cn: 被他以前的合伙人占有，没有归还给他。
options.en: His former partner occupied it and didn’t return it to him.

options.cn: 他以前的合伙人帮他管理得很好，并且归还给他了。
options.en: It had been managed well by his former partner and was returned to him.

analysis: 文中说：“He gave me an account how the farm was improved, and what it produced a year. I was now owner, all on a sudden, of more than five thousand pounds, and had a farm in the Brazils, producing more than a thousand pounds a year. ” 所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson什么时候再次去他“殖民”的小岛？
question.en: When did Robinson visit his colony on his island?

options.en: As soon as he sold his farm.
As soon as he got married.
After his wife died.

analysis: 文中说：“But my wife died, and my desire to go abroad remained. I thus decided to go as a private trader to the East Indies in the year 1694. In this voyage I visited my new colony on the island.”所以选C。

question.cn: 当Robinson再一次离开他的殖民小岛后，为什么他又送回去一艘船？
question.en: When Robinson left his colony on the island again, why did he send a ship back?

options.cn: 把岛上所有的人都接回英国。
options.en: To pick up the people on the island back to England.

options.cn: 送回一些人、牲畜和补给。
options.en: To send back with more people, livestock and supplies.

options.cn: 借给他们一艘船用来航行。
options.en: To lend them a ship for sailing.

analysis: 文中说：“In it, besides other supplies, I sent seven women...I sent them also five cows, and some pigs.”因此选B。

question.cn: Robinson和其父母对航海的观点相同吗？
question.en: Did Robinson have the same opinion about voyage as his parents?

options.en: Yes, he did.
No, he didn't.
We don't know.

analysis: 从第一章他和父母因为出海的争执可以看出，他们有不同的观点，所以选B。

question.cn: Robinson认为他的第一次前往伦敦的航行怎么样？
question.en: What did Robinson think of his first voyage heading to London?

options.cn: 他认为那是一次激动人心的航行。
options.en: He regarded it as a thrilling voyage.

options.cn: 他不喜欢，并且之后再也没有航行过。
options.en: He disliked it and never had any voyages after.

options.cn: 他被那次航行的经历吓到了。
options.en: He was frightened by the voyage.

analysis: 第二章他和同伴的对话：“How do you feel? I guess you were frightened, weren’t you, even of that little wind?” “A little wind, you call it?” said I, “It was a terrible storm.” 所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson的第一次航行成功吗？
question.en: Was Robinson's first voyage a successful one?

options.cn: 是成功的，因为他就此发财了。
options.en: Yes, it was, because it made him rich.

options.cn: 是不成功的，因为最后他们的船沉了。
options.en: No, it wasn't, because their ship sank at last.
It wasn't mentioned.

analysis: 第二章说到： “Not much more than a quarter of an hour after we left our ship, we saw it sink. ”所以选B。

question.cn: 土耳其海盗船长对 Robinson做了什么？
question.en: What did the captain of the Turkish pirate ship do to Robinson?

options.cn: 让他当另一艘海盗船的船长。
options.en: He made Robinson the captain of another pirate ship.
He threw Robinson into the sea.
He kept Robinson as a slave.

analysis: 第三章中讲到：“The rest of the sailors were taken to the ruler of the country to be his slaves, but I was kept by the captain of the pirates as his personal slave.”所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson什么时候又开始思考逃走的？
question.en: When did Robinson start to think about escape again?

options.en: When his master went to sea.

options.cn: 他主人带着他出去打鱼的时候。
options.en: When his master took him to fish.

options.cn: 他主人让他带着一个摩尔人和一个男孩出去打鱼的时候。
options.en: When his master asked him to fish with a Moor and a boy.

analysis: 第三章提到：“He told me his guests had some other business to attend to, and ordered me to take a Moor and a boy to go out to catch some fish. This moment my previous ideas of freedom returned into my thoughts. . . ”所以选C。

question.cn: Robinson在巴西做什么工作？
question.en: What did Robinson do in Brazil to make a living?

options.en: He sold land.
He managed a farm.
He made ships.

analysis: 第四章中讲到Robinson在巴西买了农场种植甘蔗，所以选B。

question.cn: 从巴西出海之前，Robinson是怎么处理他的农场的？
question.en: What did Robinson do to his farm before he went to sea from Brazil?

options.en: He sold his farm immediately.
He gave it to his neighbor for free.
He asked his neighbor to manage it for him.

analysis: 第四章中讲到他跟邻居签了合同，让邻居帮他管理农场，所以选C。

question.cn: 那些土著人是怎么处置他们的俘虏的？
question.en: How did those natives deal with their prisoners?

options.en: They buried their prisoners alive.

options.cn: 他们杀掉俘虏然后把他们扔进大海。
options.en: They killed their prisoners and threw them into the sea.

options.cn: 他们杀掉俘虏然后吃他们的肉。
options.en: They killed their prisoners and ate their flesh.

analysis: 文中多次提到那些土著人带着他们的俘虏上岸，然后杀掉俘虏，并且吃掉他们的肉。所以选C。

question.cn: 什么让Robinson到了他居住多年的小岛？
question.en: What caused Robinson's landing on the island on which he stayed for years?

options.en: The crew betrayed him.

options.cn: 船遭遇风暴，被风浪毁坏了。
options.en: Their ship met heavy storms and it was broken.
The attractive scenery on the island.

analysis: 第五章讲到由于极端天气，船失事了，但Robinson侥幸活过来上岸了。所以选B。

question.cn: 对失事的船，Robinson怎么处理的？
question.en: What did Robinson do to the broken ship?

options.cn: 在船上搜寻有用的东西。
options.en: He searched for useful things on it.
He fixed it and planned to travel again.
He dragged it to the shore.

analysis: 第五章讲到他登船多次去找可维持生存的补给。所以选A。

question.cn: Robinson做了什么以避免忘记时间？
question.en: What did Robinson do to prevent himself from forgetting time?

options.en: He made a clock.
He made marks on the rock.

options.cn: 他在柱子上划线，作为日历，并且记了日记。
options.en: He made lines on the post as a calendar and kept a diary.

analysis: 第六章里讲到Robinson做了日历并且记日记。所以选C。

question.cn: 谁制作了Robinson在岛上需要的工具？
question.en: Who made the tools Robinson needed on the island?

options.en: Robinson himself.
Friday.
The Spaniard.

analysis: Robinson作为唯一的幸存者到了孤岛上的时候，他自己建起了房子和其他的一些必需工具，所以选A。

question.cn: Robinson相信上帝吗？
question.en: Did Robinson believe in God?

options.en: Yes, he did.
No, he didn't.
We don't know.

analysis: Robinson遇到了很多危险的事件，但都化险为夷并安全回到岛上，他开始认为这些都是上帝的安排和庇佑。Robinson开始看圣经和做祷告。所以选A。

question.cn: 星期五是个怎样的人？
question.en: How was his man “Friday”?

options.en: He was ambitious.
He was loyal.
He was tricky.

analysis: 书中描述星期五都是忠诚的，听话的。 所以选B。

question.cn: 在什么前提下Robinson会救那个英国船长？
question.en: On what condition would Robinson save the English captain?

options.cn: 船长给他一些英国的货物。
options.en: The captain gave him some goods from England.
The captain gave him his ship.

options.cn: 船长把他和他的人免费带回英国。
options.en: The captain carried him and his men to England for free.

analysis: 文中Robinson提到两个条件，一是要船长不能在岛上索要任何权利，二是等夺回了他的船，就送免费Robinson和他手下的人回英国。所以选C。
